I ordered a "wagyu" burger, while my friends ordered the chicken confit and fried chicken (yes apparently they like fowl), as well as a bottle of NZ Sauvignon Blanc (the wine list is extremely limited and obviously curated to meet the $50-70 price point so you either get overpriced pedestrian village (in an attempt to satisfy the old world lovers) and a not so overpriced new world selection, since the latter tends to be cheaper anyway...so we went with the latter). My "wagyu" burger was tasty with a heavy dose of truffle derivatives/seasoning on it, but the meat/fat wasn't mind blowing so it made me wonder why bother using a low grade of wagyu just for marketing purposes. At the $20-30 range, this is likely to be Australian "wagyu" chuck though I would guess the cow is actually a mix breed, given the lack of fat and real flavor. To use a really poor analogy, its like being promised plate of char kuay teow without the fried lard - tastes fine and you can probably hide the lack of lard with some wok hei, but it's not the same. What annoyed me a little more was the doneness - I asked for my patty to be cooked medium because unlike steaks, ground meat can be quite mushy and grotesque when it is below 140F in the middle, which was the case with my burger. I sent back my burger a second time and was told by the kitchen that anything with a medium doneness will usually err on the bloody side and all I've to say is...get a good broiler or a sous vide machine? I am paying at least an arm for this burger. Anyway the accompanying sweet potato fries were fine, the fried chicken my friend ordered was crispy and juicy and the wine did its job (although our glasses were unbelievably frozen and the waiter clearly wasn't trained to pour wine). So yes, a meh passable experience. Maybe it's just me but does hipster = expensive and nothing except the coffee is supposed to taste great?

I like the bright and open feel of this cafe. Food was pretty good, especially the pancake (very fluffy and moist). The baked eggs dish could be done better with the eggs cooked a little more - so maybe you can tell them this when you order. They did forgot our order and it took a long time for try baked eggs to show up, but they didn't rush us to leave at all after we finished our food and stayed a little longer to do some girlie catch up.

Cute space. Pretty good coffee. Every item on the menu has too many elements. They take the no substitutions thing too far. I wanted ciabatta instead of foccacia under my smashed avo. Seriously. Is it really that hard? Why do you have so many different breads then?

Lobster soup - nice yummy soupStar Garoupa Fish - fresh, sauce not saltish, goodPork rib - tender, sauce not sweetBaby Kai lan with black garlic - niceClaypot rice with waxed duck, waxed pork, waxed pork sausage and waxed goose liver with a slightly saltish sauce - Duck was alright but waxed pork and sausages too stiff. They should have sliced them thinner. Of all the dishes, this is the worst. Rice also not fragrant. Not worth the calories.

address: 175 Bencoolen Street #01-55 Burlington Square Singapore 189649 Singapore
comment: Well as Marcus said below, better speak Chinese for this one. Nevertheless I managed to order in English. The coffee tasted freshly roasted and was well expressed. The pourovers were clearly poured properly, for example warming both the cone and the cup with hot water before adding filter and grounds. The space is much smaller than I thought from the photos, and very different from your usual hipster coffee hangout. There is no well labelled merchandise impeccably ordered on minimalist japano-swedish shelves, no pastel colour scheme undermining the brutality of the raw concrete and painted building bowels. Think more Ikea furniture packed with coffee making equipment and a small roaster running at the back. If there was food I did not see it. Four sandwiches are written on a board, and seem to be the only option. Coffee beans on sale (Yirgacheffe, 150g for $18; Blue Mountain for $65) were roasted on the 5th of March, a full week ago, which is the only minor issue I could find, but I know some roasters think coffee peaks 5 days after roasting.

address: 175 Bencoolen Street #01-55 Burlington Square Singapore 189649 Singapore
comment: I stumbled on this place a few weeks ago and just had my second cuppa. The coffee is great. It seems to be owned by coffee enthusiasts that are very serious about what they do. The cafe is small and there are hardly any food options but the coffee is one of the better ones I've had in Singapore. For $4, you get a really good flat white which saved my sanity. They share a space (I think) with a bakery that makes lovely cream puffs which go perfectly with the coffee. Cash only. Closes at 6pm.

address: 175 Bencoolen Street #01-55 Burlington Square Singapore 189649 Singapore
comment: I love coming in here for always excellent seriously yummy coffee, whether espresso or lattes, supplemented with the tastiest milk tea made by Elsie. Their coffees and tea are VERY good whether hot or cold although I always order the hot version but can't resist stealing a sip from my friends when they happen to get cold ones.Very affordable but delivers so much, very casual and homey atmosphere. I keep bringing friends there to hangout with our cuppas! I only wished they opened longer hours!Yummy cheesecakes too! The owners are so humble and easygoing, we've become friends.

address: 175 Bencoolen Street #01-55 Burlington Square Singapore 189649 Singapore
comment: This is one little outpost of specialty coffee geekdom, with one exception - you might need to speak Chinese.Owners Wang Tao and Elsie relocated here from Shanghai, and have started something with amazing dedication. Wang Tao is responsible for all the coffee action - he makes each coffee, be it espresso or pourover, or even the occasional syphon, AND he sources and roasts the coffee in their store, on a tiny Hottop - each batch averages 200g, so you can imagine how much time he spends roasting! He's roasted batches for some friends who've become regulars (and fast friends, especially since their command of Chinese is leagues better than mine), and the range of beans, coupled with the quality of his roast, makes him quite a rare find.Elsie is usually the face of the business, and does great front-end service, and also makes a mean Taiwan-style iced shaken tea, quite like a bubble tea. I know, it's almost blasphemous to order tea, let alone bubble tea in a specialty coffee place, but oh man. You need to try this one.If you have time for a chat, and speak decent Chinese, come here for an afternoon. I learned a lot from a fellow who's clearly a coffee nut, and loves to share it with anyone who has time to sit back and smell.... his coffee.

address: 175 Bencoolen Street #01-55 Burlington Square Singapore 189649 Singapore
comment: Lovely place to just relax and enjoy a good cup of coffee. Price isn't too bad as well.

rest_name: New Rong Ge Liang Hong Kong Roast
comment: Really good roasted meat. I managed to finally grab a plate if noodles here. This stall is always packed with a long queue.I can understand why their customers are willing to stand in line to savor this excellent roasted meat.I ordered a BBQ Char sire and roasted pork noodle, and the meat was roasted to perfection. The Char Siew was nice and charred on the outside but tender, juicy and succulent. The roasted meat was well marinated and the skin was extremely crunchy.Definitely recommended for anyone craving Hong Kong Roasted delights. Will return to savor their roasted duck soon.

The location of this place is a little tricky to find since it's a small shop, but you should see it among the tall buildings. I ordered the injeolmi bingsoo, which is Korean rice cake with soya bean, red bean mochi pieces, sesame ice cream with almonds and peanut, all topped with condensed milk. The shaved ice was very loose and fluffy. My suggestion would be to add more rice cake, red bean, etc.. on the bottom since there's really not much there... But overall it's a good place to grab shaved ice with your friends on a hot day (which is basically everyday).

address: 112 Middle Rd #01-00B Midland House Singapore 188970 Singapore
comment: Looking for best sushi place in Singapore. Google showed most active reviews. I'm glad to find out about En Sushi. It was the reliable choice over another place I was going to.Very happy to have dinner here my first night in Singapore. Great staff, friendly. Easy walk from hotel. Food was tasty and fresh! I would reorder the same should I return.

address: 112 Middle Rd #01-00B Midland House Singapore 188970 Singapore
comment: This is a no-frills japanese seafood restaurant, located at the old K-Tower seafood restaurant, that was a seafood gimmick that failed, the owners decided to turn it around and serve what youngsters these days crave for. Bara chirashidon at $10.80++ . The serving of the seafood is value for money, though there could be more rice served. The sashimi slices are thick and again, very generous. The location is right smack in the middle of dhoby ghaut mrt and bras basah mrt. Lots of private schools around, including SOTA and SMU. There's even a nine fresh dessert stall next to it, for below $3 chinese sweet jelly desserts.I love the concept, and I think it can do well, though I noted that the business was kind of quiet on a weekday, I'm sure it will fare better on the weekend.But comparing this to sushiro, sushiro is way more value for money at $12.80 nett.

address: 112 Middle Rd #01-00B Midland House Singapore 188970 Singapore
comment: Straightforward sushi joint. The chirashi dons as pretty reasonably priced, the fish tastes fine, not spectacular but not cheap. It's a nice atmosphere and is well run with good service, so if you're looking for a simple sushi fix it'll certainly do the trick.

Enjoyed a tasty meal at this place with a friend. It was surprisingly good and one of the better hokkien mee dishes I've eaten. The ones you find at hawkers here are usually too wet and starchy for my liking but the chef got it just right and I was very tempted to order a second serving.The stall is located at Blk 269B. It's easy to walk to the wrong hawker centre as there is a much larger and livelier hawker centre (Albert Complex) nearby. To get to this place, just remember it's directly opposite Bugis+ shopping mall.Food takes a littlw while to come but it's very worth the wait for a well-cooked plate of hokkien mee. I also like how the chef separates the lard from the main dish for those who are more health conscious like me.Will definitely be back here to introduce my family and friends and get my hokkien mee fix! Thumbs up!

address: 8 Wilkie Rd #01-05, Wilkie Edge Singapore 228095 Singapore
comment: Tried this after reading Jackay's review! Went on a Friday night.The selection for toppings is endless. from kimchi to century eggs and there are safe selections too. Interestingly, they serve waffles, soups and other desserts too.I had a wrap+chicken+5 toppings and my partner had a single salad consisting of 5 toppings. It cost under $16 and was very fulfiling. This is easily one of the most value for money salad places in Singapore, besides cold storage. Others are incredibly overpriced!The staff recommended me to take an extra meat but I declined so it can make me 'full' as I chose mainly light ingredients.  A constant stream of customers arrived, most likely Kaplan students. Happy Tummy is new to market, and I saw on their Fb that they are opening a new outlet at Yishun! Lucky Yishunittes..Definitely coming back to try!

address: 8 Wilkie Rd #01-05, Wilkie Edge Singapore 228095 Singapore
comment: Happy Tummy, Happy Yummy! This is my all-time favourite salad bar. I probably go there twice a week. Fresh ingredients, friendly peeps and so much cheaper than Salad Stop!A Single, gets you a base of romaine and 5 toppings for $6.80. A Double (which supposedly feeds 2 peeps, but I eat it all by myself. Moo!) gets you a generous base of romaine and 8 toppings, all for $10. They also give unlimited herbs and condiments, like basil, oregeno, parsley, fried shallots, garlic and sesame seeds. I usually get the Roasted Sesame or Miso Sesame dressing. Premium items, like spinach, roast chicken or freshly grilled salmon (made in house), cost anything from $1 to $2.50 more each. Even then, my Doubles never cost more than $13. If I went to Salad Stop, I'd get half the amount for the same price. And for half the smiles too. (Alright, I'll stop knocking Salad Stop!) They also serve wraps, soups, ice-cream waffles, cold pressed juices, coffee/tea and baked goods like macaroons, muffins, tarts. But I'm usually there to eat "clean", so I just take in the smells. There is a seating area for about 15-20, but it looks a little crammed, so I usually take out. Probably not good for big groups. If you're a student/staff from SMU, Kaplan, NAFA or Lasalle, you get one free additional topping, and if you are from RSM International, the Ascott Limited or Citadines, you get a special discount. They also have a loyalty card. 4 orders gets you a free topping, 8 gets you a free premium, and 13 gets you a free Single salad. I LOVE HAPPY TUMMY!

address: 8 Wilkie Rd #01-05, Wilkie Edge Singapore 228095 Singapore
comment: Not the highest quality ingredients, but a welcome breath of fresh air in a mall with very few cheap decent options. I got stuck in Wilkie by the rain. It was lunchtime so I thought why not. The position of the restaurant is quite nice, having the seating in a corner means a spacious view including on the street (seeing the sky in a mall! who'd have thought), although the tables are very close together and you will bump into people. The burger patty definitely came from the freezer as did the sliced Kraft cheese on top. Salad was alright, although a few of the grapes were very soft. The sesame dressing was great, the chef has taste. The lemonade was enjoyable and did not have the cleaning fluid feel of the artificial stuff you find in food courts.  I just want to point out this is not a hipster salad bar with specially imported ingredients, just Cold Storage/Fairprice stuff thrown together at an attractive price, not a destination, but a good place to hang out if you already live here. Definitely a good option for a traditional breakfast, and I guess I should try the salads people are raving about. All in all, but a welcome addition to Wilkie for those of us who just want a simple healthy lunch without paying $20 at any of the mediocre "food concepts" nearby. Together with the arrival of Hao Wei Lai opposite, things are looking up in the not-hipster, not-hawker segment for the neighbourhood.

address: 8 Wilkie Rd #01-05, Wilkie Edge Singapore 228095 Singapore
comment: Affordable salad with a wide selection. Ideal location right beneath my classroom making it a definite choice for me for lunch or dinner before and after class. Love coming for the wide array of food and the friendly staff

address: 180 Albert St #01-19B, Village HOTEL Alberts Court Singapore 189971 Singapore
comment: A fine spot for vegetarians who want some respite from the usual SE Asia fare. Lots of non-meat options.

address: 180 Albert St #01-19B, Village HOTEL Alberts Court Singapore 189971 Singapore
comment: This place is my top find of the last few months.  The fact that it's in Albert Court (one of my favorite corners of the city but a place that can't seem to keep a decent restaurant open) makes it all the better.  The six or seven dishes I've tried here have all been very good and the price is reasonable. Pizzas, steak, grilled chicken breast, and chef salad are all simple but delicious. The chef and managers' shy but friendly service, the adorable plaid plastic table cloths, and the reliably good house wine at 6$ a glass all make Mangiamo a sure bet.

address: 180 Albert St #01-19B, Village HOTEL Alberts Court Singapore 189971 Singapore
comment: I think there are more food to enjoy in this place, I visited it once this week and I will be coming back to taste more of the food they are serving.Had wine and pizza, for tourists this is the place to have that wine before bed time or after shopping around the area. Near Little India, Sim Lim SQ., La Salle.

Amazing dim sum. There are prawn dim sum not on the menu as they take a few minutes to do. So try everything.  A friend brought me here and we tried the whole menu.  All tasty find your favorite.  I came back a second time in my own and it was just add good.  First time was breakfast second time was lunch.  I could eat this any time.

I'd give this place a solid 3.5 stars. It's small absolutely no frills and cheap. So don't expect great things. That being said, it offers value for money meals. Some things on the menu are reliably good. The steamed chicken rice and spare ribs on rice are good for a meal for modest eaters. I like that they add wolfberries to the chicken for a touch of sweet and colour. The ribs are always tender and cooked just right. The prawn dumpling soup has generously stuffed dumplings livened with shredded black fungus and shrimp, crunchy goodness! And the soup is tasty without giving you an msg attack. The glutinous rice with chicken and sausage in lotus leaf is nicely made, and goes superbly with the chilli sauce. And the chilli sauce is the bomb. Made inhouse, it is larded through generously with superbly crispy garlic chips. Love love love that sauce! If they bottle it I would so buy it. The siew mai and char siew buns are also hearty and rustic which is part of their charm. If you know what to expect, this is a good place to pop by for quick cheap eats.
Not impressed... The taste is just okay, small stall also... Won't go again for sure...

Fresh craft beer was a sometime thing in Singapore.  I'm glad to report that this is changing.  There are a few obvious reasons that the quality of craft beer is making leaps in the right direction, namely that there is a growing demand for the same taste and experience that Singaporeans traveling overseas have enjoyed at taprooms, craft beer bars, and breweries around the world.  Demand drives turnover and with a young fresh product like beer, rapid turnover means all kinds of good things for the consumer.  In this regard, beer is a little like cheese, it starts dying the minute it is kegged and the sooner you have it, the better the experience, the closer it will be to what the brewer intended.  The people who store and serve beer are also getting more knowledgeable about the product and also about how to properly handle it.  This may be less of an issue with spirits and wine, but improperly stored, handled, or poured beer will result in a vastly inferior tasting ride.  Finally,  and to me, most importantly, establishments are beginning to invest in facilities to properly store beer and the American Taproom is one of a small handful of establishments that have a cold room to allow the kegs to reach the desired temperature and then hold them there till they are completely served out.  This means that your beer was treated right instead of the less "honorable" method of running beer from room-temperature kegs through a cooling system before it runs out the tap and into your cup.  This second way of handling and serving beer is still very common in Singapore and if you've ever wondered why your beer taps foamy in Singapore, this is as likely a culprit as any. So in addition to having a truly impressive selection, the American Taproom makes it a point to receive only fresh product, store and handle it properly, all in order to serve you the beer the brewer intended you to have.The kitchen at the American Taproom also puts out some really creditable bar food which is hearty, tasty and provides a solid complement to the tap list.

Really nice place to chill out and have a few craft beers with a friend. The location is a little offbeat as it's parked under a residential building in a little corner so have some patience when you look for it.They also have a pizza and small bites menu I didn't try. We asked the staff for some recommendations and were really happy. My friend has a sweet tooth and they recommended him a cinnamon cider on tap which he loved. I had a black raspberry sour ale which I loved too. The atmosphere is dark and nice for coming with the lads.
